metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data set of Paleozoic-Early Mesozoic sedimentary rocks  in Yunnan Ailaoshan and Baoshan area (202-543 Ma)
metadata.description: The data set includes: longitude and latitude, lithological information, chronological data, O isotope composition and major and trace element composition of sedimentary rock samples from Permian Triassic and Cambrian Silurian clastic strata in Ailaoshan structural belt and Baoshan area, Yunnan Province. The chronological data of rock samples are determined by laser ablation plasma mass spectrometry (la-mc-icpms) of detrital zircon, and the error of Single Zircon 91500 is less than 5%; The main elements were determined by X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) by melting the rock powder into a glass sheet which can be tested on the computer. The analytical accuracy of the standard materials gbw-07111, gbw-123, gsr-1, gsr-2 and gsr-3 was better than 2%; Trace elements were analyzed by Perkin Elmer Elan 6000 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). In the process of analysis and test, USGS reference materials (bhvo-2, avg-2, gsr-1, gsr-2, gsr-3, gsd-9 and sarm-4) were determined. As the external test standard, the element content of the test sample was more accurate than 3%. The oxygen isotope data are obtained by SIMS of detrital zircon. The external accuracy of the multiple determination results of Penglai standard sample is better than 0.30 ‰ (2 σ，  n = 24)。 The obtained detrital zircon age spectrum of Permian Triassic clastic sedimentary rocks in Ailaoshan, as well as major and trace element compositions, can be used to effectively limit the evolution process of ancient Tethys Ailaoshan Ocean from subduction to closure, which has been published in international well-known journals such as tectonics, GSA bulletin and Journal of Asian Earth Sciences, And the famous domestic journal geotectonics and mineralization. The data can be widely used in the future to limit the study of the evolution history of the paleo ocean basin. The obtained detrital zircon age spectrum and Hf isotope data of Cambrian Devonian clastic rocks in Baoshan area can be used to effectively limit the tectonic position of Baoshan block in the early Paleozoic. The relevant data have been published in the well-known domestic journal Acta petrologica, and the data can be widely used in the reconstruction of Gondwana continent in the future.
metadata.instructions:
File name: rock longitude and latitude, major and trace element content, zircon age data and zircon oxygen isotope data are stored in Excel format, and the file name is "Paleozoic early Mesozoic stratigraphic geochemical data set (2016-2019) in Ailaoshan Baoshan area, Yunnan Province"
Data reading mode: it can be directly opened by Microsoft Excel

Feature Specification.Question: What are the methods used to determine the geochemical characteristics of sedimentary rock samples from the Paleozoic to Early Mesozoic eras in a dataset?
Feature Specification.Answer: LA-MC-ICPMS for zircon age data, XRF for major elements, ICP-MS for trace elements, SIMS for oxygen isotope data

Quantification.Question: What is the measurement precision for main elements when using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry in a dataset focusing on sedimentary rock samples from geological regions?

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using laser ablation multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICPMS) for zircon dating compare to those using secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) for oxygen isotope data in terms of precision and applicability in geological studies?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection method using LA-MC-ICPMS for zircon dating provides precise age data with an error margin better than 5% for standard samples, making it highly useful for establishing detailed age spectra of sedimentary rocks. Meanwhile, the SIMS technique for collecting oxygen isotope data achieves an external precision of better than 0.30‰ for multiple determinations of the standard sample Penglai, which is crucial for understanding isotopic variations. Both methods are applicable in geological studies, but LA-MC-ICPMS is primarily focused on dating, whereas SIMS is focused on isotopic composition.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the tectonic evolution processes from the geochemical patterns observed in the sedimentary rock samples collected from the Permian-Triassic Ailao Shan tectonic zone and the Cambrian-Silurian Baoshan area?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical patterns, including detrital zircon age spectra and major and trace element compositions, can be used to effectively constrain the evolution process of the Paleo-Tethys Ailao Shan ocean from subduction to closure. These patterns have been published in international journals like Tectonics, GSA Bulletin, and Journal of Asian Earth Sciences, indicating their significance in understanding the tectonic evolution. Additionally, the detrital zircon age spectra and Hf isotopic data from the Baoshan area's Cambrian-Devonian sedimentary rocks can be instrumental in determining the tectonic position of the Baoshan block during the Early Paleozoic, and these findings have been published in the domestic journal 'Acta Petrologica Sinica', showing potential for future research on Gondwana reconstruction.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on geochemical data accuracy when using detrital zircon age data from laser ablation multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICPMS) compared to other dating methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using detrital zircon age data from laser ablation multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICPMS) can result in high precision with errors better than 5% for standard samples like single grain zircon 91500, potentially leading to more accurate age determination of sedimentary rock samples from regions such as Yunnan's Ailaoshan-Baoshan areas. This accuracy is crucial for understanding the evolution from subduction to closure of ancient oceanic basins like the Paleo-Tethys Ocean.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting geochemical data from sedimentary rock samples in the Ailao Mountain-Baoshan region for understanding Paleozoic to early Mesozoic stratigraphic evolution?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to effectively constrain the evolution of the Paleo-Tethys Ailao Mountain ocean from subduction to closure, utilizing the detrital zircon age spectra and major-trace element compositions obtained from the sedimentary rock samples. This data can be widely cited in research studying the evolutionary history of ancient ocean basins.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to collect and analyze geochemical data from sedimentary rock samples in the field of stratigraphy and geochemistry of ancient geological formations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the field of stratigraphy and geochemistry of ancient geological formations, the procedures to collect and analyze geochemical data from sedimentary rock samples involve several steps: determining the location and collecting sedimentary rock samples, identifying rock lithology, obtaining geochronological data through LA-MC-ICPMS on detrital zircon with an error margin better than 5%, measuring major elements by fusing rock powder into testable glass disks and analyzing them using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) with an accuracy better than 2%, analyzing trace elements using ICP-MS with an accuracy better than 3%, and obtaining oxygen isotope data through SIMS on detrital zircon with an external precision better than 0.30‰.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements or methodologies have enabled the precise determination of sample geochemistry and isotopic composition in stratigraphic studies of ancient geological formations?
Enablement.Answer: The use of laser ablation multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICPMS) has enabled precise determination of zircon age data, with an error margin of less than 5% for standard samples. Additionally, the main elements are measured by X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) with an accuracy of better than 2% for standard materials, and trace elements are analyzed using Perkin-Elmer ELAN 6000 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) with an accuracy better than 3% for standard materials. Secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) provides oxygen isotope data with an external precision better than 0.30‰ (2σ, n = 24).
